name: Section 5 - Cabin Operations (CAB)
applicability:
Applicability
Section 5 addresses the safety and security requirements associated with the aircraft passenger cabin. All
standards and recommended practices (ISARPs) in this section are applicable to an operator that
conducts passenger flights with cabin crew.
Individual CAB provisions or sub-specifications within a CAB provision that:
 Do not begin with a conditional phrase are applicable unless determined otherwise by the Auditor.
 Begin with a conditional phrase  If the Operator...  are applicable if the Operator meets the
condition(s) stated in the phrase.
 Begin with a conditional phrase  If the Operator conducts passenger flights with or without cabin
crew   are applicable if the Operator conducts passenger flights without cabin crew.
Additional ISARPs applicable to an operator that conducts passenger flights without cabin crew are
located in Section 2 (FLT) of this manual.
Specifications applicable to the carriage of supernumeraries are located in Section 2 (FLT) of this manual.
Where an operator outsources the performance of cabin operations functions to external service providers,
the operator retains overall responsibility for ensuring the management of safety in such operations and
must demonstrate processes for monitoring applicable external service providers in accordance with
CAB 1.10.2 .
guidance:
General Guidance
Definitions of technical terms used in this ISM Section 5 , as well as the meaning of abbreviations and
acronyms, are found in the IATA Reference Manual for Audit Programs (IRM).
Refer to the IATA Cabin Operations Best Practices Guide for practical information and guidance related to
cabin safety policies and procedures, (http://www.iata.org/publications/Pages/cabin-safety-guide.aspx ).
1 Management and Control
1.1 Management System Overview

items.paragraph: The Operator shall have a management system for the cabin operations organization that ensure ontrol of cabin crew operations in the passenger cabin and the management of safety and securit utcomes.

The Operator shall have a process or procedure for the delegation of duties within the cabi perations management system that ensures managerial continuity is maintained when operationa anagers including, if applicable, post holders are unable to carry out work duties.

The Operator shall ensure a delegation of authority and assignment of responsibility within th anagement system for liaison with regulatory authorities, original equipment manufacturers an ther external entities relevant to cabin operations.
The Operator shall ensure the duties and responsibilities of cabin crew members are defined an escribed in the Operations Manual (OM).
The Operator shall ensure cabin crew members maintain familiarity with laws, regulations an rocedures pertinent to the performance of their duties.

The Operator shall have processes to ensure information relevant to cabin crew policies, procedure nd responsibilities is communicated to all cabin crew members, and to ensure essential operationa nformation or guidance is communicated to the cabin crew prior to each flight.
The Operator shall have the necessary facilities, workspace, equipment and supporting services, a ell as work environment, to satisfy cabin operations safety and security requirements.

The Operator shall have a selection process for management and non-management positions withi abin operations organization that require the performance of functions relevant to the safety o ecurity of cabin operations. Such process shall ensure candidates are selected on the basis o nowledge, skills, training and experience appropriate for the position.

The Operator shall have an Operations Manual (OM), which may be issued in separate parts, tha ontains the policies, procedures and other guidance or information necessary for cabin cre embers to perform their duties and be in compliance with applicable regulations, laws, rules an perator standards. The content of the OM shall be in accordance with specifications i able 5.1 .
If required by the Authority, the Operator shall have a process to ensure the OM, including update nd revisions, is submitted for acceptance or approval.

The Operator shall have a process to ensure cabin crew members are issued or have direct acces o, as a minimum, those parts of the OM that address duties and responsibilities relevant to the safet nd security of cabin operations.
The Operator shall have a process to ensure holders of the OM enter the most current amendment r revisions into the manual and maintain the manual in an up-to-date condition.
The Operator shall ensure information in the OM pertaining to cabin crew duties and responsibilitie s published in the designated common language(s) of the Operator, as specified in CAB 3.1.3 .

If the Operator publishes a practical manual for use by the cabin crew in the performance of cabi perations duties, the Operator shall ensure one or more copies of the up-to-date practical manua re on board the aircraft for passenger flights and located in a manner that provides for immediat ccess by each cabin crew member.
If the Operator uses an electronic system for the management and control of cabin operation ecords, the Operator shall ensure the system provides for a scheduled generation of backup recor iles.
The Operator shall have a process to ensure significant issues arising from cabin operations qualit ssurance and risk management are subject to management review in accordance with ORG 4.1.1 .

The Operator shall ensure all cabin crew members complete a recurrent training course once ever 2 months or, if applicable, in accordance with the Operator's AQP as specified in CAB 2.1.1B i rder to remain qualified to perform duties as a cabin crew member.

The Operator shall ensure the completion of required training by cabin crew members is recorde nd such records are retained in accordance with CAB 1.7.1 .

recognition and emergency action.

The Operator shall ensure cabin crew members receive training in human performance to gain a nderstanding of the human factors involved in conducting cabin safety duties and coordinating wit he flight crew during the execution of onboard emergency procedures.

The Operator should ensure cabin crew members participate in joint training activities or exercise ith flight crew members for the purpose of enhancing onboard coordination and mutua nderstanding of the human factors involved in addressing emergency situations and securit hreats.

If the Operator uses aircraft that require more than one cabin crew member, the Operator shal nsure applicable cabin crew members have completed cabin crew leadership training (if applicable,
as approved or accepted by the Authority) prior to being assigned to duties as a designated cabi rew leader, in accordance with CAB 3.1.2 .

The Operator shall ensure cabin crew members complete supervised line flight experience as part o he cabin crew initial qualification process and prior to being assigned unsupervised duties as a cabi rew member. Supervised line flight experience shall be completed during one or more actual lin light segments and shall require a cabin crew member to demonstrate an understanding of al esponsibilities and competency to perform the duties and execute the procedures associated wit abin operations.

If the Operator uses aircraft that require only one cabin crew member, the Operator shall ensur abin crew members complete supervised line flight experience on such aircraft as part of the cabi rew qualification or re-qualification process and prior to being assigned to perform unsupervise uties on an aircraft as the sole operating cabin crew member.

The Operator should ensure cabin crew members complete supervised line flight experience as par f the cabin crew re-qualification process and prior to being assigned unsupervised duties on an ircraft requiring more than one cabin crew member.
The Operator should ensure cabin crew members receive a periodic line evaluation or check whil erforming their duties during line operations.

The Operator shall have a program that ensures its cabin operations personnel are trained an ompetent to perform SMS duties. The scope of such training shall be appropriate to eac ndividual's involvement in the SMS.

If the Operator outsources cabin operations functions to external service providers, the Operato hould have a program that ensures personnel of external service providers are trained an ompetent to perform SMS duties. The scope of such training should be appropriate to individua nvolvement in the Operator s SMS.

If the Operator uses aircraft that require more than one cabin crew member, the Operator shal nsure, for flights on such aircraft:

	(i) Designation of a suitably qualified cabin crew leader who has overall responsibility for th onduct and coordination of normal and emergency cabin procedures.

	(ii) A defined delegation of leadership duties during inflight rest periods and/or in the event o nexpected incapacitation of the cabin crew leader.

The Operator shall have procedures to ensure communication between the cabin crew and fligh rew during line operations is conducted in the designated common language(s) of the Operator, a pecified in FLT 3.1.1 .

The Operator shall have a methodology for the purpose of managing fatigue-related safety risks t nsure fatigue occurring in one flight, successive flights or accumulated over a period of time doe ot impair a cabin crew member's alertness and ability to perform safety-related cabin duties. Suc ethodology shall consist of:

	(i) Flight time, flight duty period, duty period limitations and rest period requirements that are i ccordance with the applicable prescriptive fatigue management regulations of the State,
and/or,

	(ii) If applicable, the Operator's Fatigue Risk Management System (FRMS) approved o ccepted by the State and established in accordance with CAB 3.1.4B .

If the Operator uses an FRMS to manage cabin crew fatigue-related safety risks, the Operator shoul nsure the organizational activities specified in CAB 3.1.4B related to the management of cabin cre atigue-related risks are integrated with the Operator's organizational safety management system(SMS) as specified in ORG 1.1.10 .

The Operator shall have a process to ensure flight time, flight duty periods and rest periods for cabi rew members are recorded and retained for a minimum period of time in accordance with applicabl egulations.

If the Operator uses aircraft equipped with cabin doors that have an automatic slide or slide/raf eployment system, the Operator shall have cabin crew procedures for arming and disarming suc oor systems.
The Operator should require cabin crew members to be seated with their safety harnesses fastene hen the aircraft is taxiing, except to perform safety-related duties.

The Operator shall have cabin crew procedures for providing passengers with instructions fo ppropriate action in the case of an in-flight emergency situation.

If the Operator uses aircraft with electrical system circuit breakers that are accessible to cabin cre embers, the Operator shall have procedures that specify limitations for resetting tripped circui reakers by cabin crew members during flight.
The Operator shall have procedures to ensure the cabin crew provides notification to the flight cre hen a safety-related situation has been identified.

The Operator should have a policy and procedures that define and specify the requirements fo tandard wording, terminology, signals and/or verbal commands used for communication betwee abin crew and flight crew during normal, abnormal and emergency situations.

If the Operator conducts passenger flights with or without cabin crew, the Operator shall hav rocedures that require the secure restraint of infants during the phases of flight and condition pecified in CAB 3.4.4 .

If the Operator conducts passenger flights with or without cabin crew and uses aircraft that hav assenger seats adjacent to cabin emergency exits, the Operator shall have guidance an rocedures to ensure passengers seated in such seats meet any applicable requirements an estrictions.

If the Operator conducts passenger flights with or without cabin crew, the Operator shall hav uidelines and associated procedures to ensure control of the use of portable electronic devices i he passenger cabin.
The Operator shall have cabin crew procedures that ensure passengers are briefed on matter elated to safety, including turbulence, normal, abnormal and emergency situations.

The Operator shall have a policy that defines the acceptance or non-acceptance of passengers tha ave the potential need for supplementary oxygen and, if such passengers are accepted, procedure or the administration and stowing of supplementary oxygen.

The Operator shall ensure the immediate availability of procedures and associated checklist(s),
applicable to each aircraft type, to be used for an in-flight search or inspection to discover conceale eapons, explosives, or other dangerous devices when sabotage or other type of unlawfu nterference is suspected. Such procedures shall contain:

	(i) Guidance for the course of action to be taken if a bomb or suspicious object is found;

	(ii) Least risk location(s) for a bomb or explosives specific to each aircraft type, if so designate y the manufacturer.

The Operator shall have a process that permits the cabin crew to report the existence of non-
serviceable aircraft equipment prior to and after the completion of a flight.
